head.hi:
INTERESTING CORRESPONDENCE BETWEEN
BARON HUMBOLDT AND THE MEXICAN GO-
VERNMENT.

p.hi:
(Translated from the Mexican Sol, of March 19, 1825.)
Letter addressed by the Minister of Relations, to Baron Alex-
ander Humboldt.

div.p:
Your luminous writings relative to America, the fruit of your
talents and of your travels in this part of the globe, have been
generally received with the estimation due to the interesting
matter and information with which they abound. From them
can be formed a correct idea of what Mexico will be, under a
good and liberal Constitution, possessing as it does, within itself,
all the elements of prosperity; and the reading of your work,
has not a little contributed to vivify the spirit of independence,
the germs of which existed amongst many of the inhabit-
ants, and to arouse others from the lethargy in which they
were held by foreign domination. The whole nation
is penetrated with gratitude for your labours, as they
have been the means of making known to the world
its capacity of rendering itself happy in itself; and
the supreme Government charged with the administration of
its public concerns, heartily concur in this respect with the ge-
neral sentiment. The Government has, therefore, been pleased
to direct me, as their Minister of State and Relations, to express
to you the great satisfaction with which they have understood it
to be your intention to return once more to this country, and
their lively hope that you will carry that idea into effect, so that
they may congratulate themselves on counting amongst the num-
ber of the inhabitants of this republic, a man so illustrious and
justly esteemed throughout the civilized world. In communi-
cating to you these sentiments and wishes of my government, I
take the more pleasure as it affords me an opportunity of repeat-
ing to you the expression of my high consideration and respect.

In an official letter of the 21st July, your Excellency has been
pleased to transmit to me the sentiments of affection and esteem
with which the Mexican nation and their government deign to
honour my slender literary labours. Engaged in a career dedi-
cated entirely to the cultivation of the sciences, and to the sup-
port of the eternal principles on which the progress of reason,
and the amelioration of public institutions depend, nothing could
flatter my self-love more than this solemn testimony, expressed in
so noble and interesting a manner. I therefore beg your Excel-
lency to present to your Government this homage of my pro-
found respect, and of my eternal gratitude. If the works which
I have published have produced any good, it should be attri-
buted only to my love for the truth and the purity of my senti-
ments, and to the admiration with which I have been inspired by
a country whom nature has destined to so exalted a fate. I am
not without hope of beholding once again (my sovereign
permitting) the majestic Corderillas of Anàhuac; of studying
once more their natural productions; and of enjoying the plea-
sure of witnessing the progressive happiness which must neces-
sarily be produced in the bosom of the Republic by free institu-
tions and the arts of peace. In requesting your Excellency to
be the organ of my gratitude to the supreme Government, I seize
the occasion to reiterate to you the sentiments of high considera-
tion and esteem with which I have the honour to be, your most
humble and obedient servant,

p.hi:
To his Excellency Lucas Alaman, Secretary of State
for the Mexican Republic.

div.p: Letter of Baron Humboldt, to the President of the Republic.

Most Excellent Sir—With the most respectful confidence, I
address myself to the first Magistrate of the Mexican Republic,
to him whom the free suffrages of the nation have just called to
a post so much the more eminent, as it affords the faculty of
using clemency, and of alleviating the sufferings of the unfor-
tunate. How satisfactory to me is the consideration, that the
first time that I present myself before the Supreme Government
of a country, whose riches and natural resources I have made
known to Europe, my supplications may procure consolation for
an unfortunate family! I have this day learnt that Col. Carlos
Benesky, with whom I am not personally acquainted (although
he is from the Prussian colony, and my countryman)
but who has done signal services in the last wars of my
country, has been induced by an error of political opinion,
to follow the fortunes of Augustin Iturbide. An aged
father and two sisters, of respectable connections, fear that
he has forfeited his life. They have applied to me, hoping that
my voice will be listened to, and that my prayers may be suffi-
cient to obtain the liberty of a son and a brother, whose resi-
dence in America was even unknown on the banks of the Rhine.

The Old World has admired the generous sentiments displayed
by the Mexican nation, in their conduct towards the family of
the Ex-Emperor. Deign, then, your Excellency, as a distin-
guished favour to me, to extend that national clemency to Co-
lonel Benesky, and for the sake of his unfortunate father, to
commute his punishment into merely banishment from the terri-
tory of the Republic. Emboldened by my known attachment to
a country for which your Excellency has made so great and
noble sacrifices, I make this supplication with the most perfect
confidence.—I am, with the most profound respect, Mr. Presi-
dent, your Excellency’s most humble and obedient servant,

p.hi:
To his Excellency Gen. Guadalupe Victoria, President of the
Mexican Republic.

div.p:
[The wishes of Baron H. were anticipated, Colonel Benesky
having been merely sent out of the country, some time before
the above letter was received.]
